title: The Carpenter's Tower
devotional:
Old Man Tiberius, a weathered carpenter known for his sturdy creations, faced a peculiar challenge. A fierce storm had ravaged the village, leaving the church's bell tower unstable. The elders, desperate, turned to Tiberius. He was old and his hands weren't as steady as they used to be, but his reputation for resilience preceded him. Tiberius surveyed the damage, the wind still howling a mournful tune. Doubts gnawed at him. Could he, with his aging body, truly restore the tower to its former glory? The task seemed insurmountable.

That night, unable to sleep, Tiberius stumbled upon an old, leather-bound book his grandfather, also a carpenter, had left him. He found a passage marked with a faded ribbon: 'My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.' These words struck a chord deep within him. He realised that his physical limitations were not a hindrance but an opportunity for God's strength to shine through. 

The next morning, a renewed sense of purpose filled Tiberius. He didn't deny his weakness, but he embraced it, acknowledging his need for divine assistance. He started the repairs, each swing of the hammer a prayer, each placement of a beam a testament to his faith. Villagers watched, initially skeptical, but soon, their skepticism turned into admiration as they witnessed Tiberius's unwavering determination and the gradual restoration of the tower. He worked tirelessly, fuelled not by his own strength, but by the limitless power of God working through him.

In the end, the bell tower stood stronger than before, a symbol of resilience and a testament to the strength that comes from acknowledging our weakness and relying on God's grace. Tiberius, the old carpenter, had not only repaired a tower but had also strengthened the faith of an entire village.
image_description: An old wooden church bell tower stands silhouetted against a sunrise, surrounded by trees with autumn foliage.
insights: Paul's words in 2 Corinthians 12:9, 'My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness,' are central to understanding the source of true strength. It's counterintuitive, but biblical. God's power isn't diminished by our weakness; rather, our weakness becomes the canvas upon which His strength is displayed. This isn't about celebrating incompetence but recognizing that when we acknowledge our limitations and rely on God, He can work through us in ways we never thought possible. The story of Gideon (Judges 6-7) further illustrates this, where God uses a small, seemingly insignificant army to defeat a much larger enemy, demonstrating that victory comes from God, not human might.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often struggle with feelings of inadequacy and weakness. I try to rely on my own strength, only to find myself falling short. Today, I surrender my weaknesses to You, trusting that Your grace is sufficient for me. Fill me with Your power, so that I may accomplish Your will, not through my own might, but through Your Spirit. Help me to remember that Your strength is made perfect in my weakness. In Jesus’ name, I pray. Amen.
reflection: In what areas of your life do you feel weak or inadequate? How can you shift your perspective to see these weaknesses as opportunities for God's strength to be displayed? What practical steps can you take to rely more on God's grace and less on your own abilities?
